latest_10_reviews.review_title: In my top 10 Christmas movies to watch every year!
latest_10_reviews.review_text: This movie never gets old for me! The TV puns are witty playing off the timeless classic and modernize it to fit the cut throat TV industry, and a desensitized generation.Bill Murray is at his best with his zany SNL throwbacks, impressions and being funny the way he used to be (although I haven't seen him in ages.) The ghosts of past & present (Carol Kane) & Bob Cathwaite are hilarious. Other role players including John Forsythe and Robert Mitchum provide good characterization. This movie is 35 years old and it never gets old as my family and I can recite the lines in this film verbatim and laugh every time.

This is, for me, one of Bill Murray's best performances, even though it is unhinged. He plays a network executive who is clearly unhappy with the choices he has made, and through the magic of Christmas he is visited by three ghosts like in a Christmas Carol. It is a retelling of it, but one that is more modern, and still firm set in the greed is good era of the 1980s. This film came out when I was eleven, and I think my parents picked up a VHS copy shortly after. I wanted to watch a Christmas movie with my kids, and they didn't want to watch Gremlins for some reason, so I chose this one. I remember every little detail, and the practical effects are amazing. The rotting corpse whose arm gets torn off is still creepy today. It's a pretty dark Christmas film, which leads to me to wonder why were the films of my childhood a bit dark, and now films for children are so antiseptic?

latest_10_reviews.review_title: Has it's moments, but overall falls flat
latest_10_reviews.review_text: The movie starts off decent but then falls apart at about the halfway mark. I think a modern day revamp. (for the 80's) was a great idea, and kudos with Scrooge being a ruthless, disconnected TV exec, but there was just so much more left to be desired in this version of the classic Dicken's tale. As the film goes on, it just starts to become nonsense and many scenes are just loud and irritating. The ghost of Christmas present was downright terrible and completely unfunny. I had a bit of difficulty following the film as it was all over the place and it felt like it's was just jumping from scene to scene without any direction. The biggest issue was that, for a rendition of A Christmas Carol, it lacked heart. The ending felt rushed and disjointed and seeing Scrooge's redemption, which is my favorite part of the story, was so unsatisfying. All in all, the movie is mostly unfunny, annoying, dull, and rather simple minded. It also lacks that emotion other versions really captured with this story. If you're considering watching it, I say give this one a pass.

Bill Murray is hilarious as this modern version of Ebeneezer Scrooge. The whole movie is comic genius from start to finish. And while you would think that the spirit of xmas would be lost with this approach, the movie remains nostalgic and really brings the feel good factor that is required in a xmas movie. The supporting cast are also fantastic with Bobcat Goldthwait delivering a brilliant and again hilarious performance. The Movie is defo of the era with similarities to other Bill Murray Classics such as groundhog day. By far my favourite Xmas movie and a real treat for all the family. I am very much a traditionalist when it comes to Christmas Entertainment, but if you want something that is a bit leftfield but still makes you come back for that xmas hit , year after year. You can't go wrong with Scrooged.

"Scrooged" is one of the most hilarious Christmas films ever made but it's surprisingly controversial or at least unpopular among some fans of Christmas movies. Maybe it's expectations. For those who say it's not a literal version of Dickens' story, well, it's not. It's inspired and loosely based on it. Many people complain that the character is too dark or that they can't like him enough to root for him. But this is not "It's a Wonderful Life" and Bill Murray isn't Jimmy Stewart. I don't think anyone watching any of the actual films of "A Christmas Carol" or even reading the story would say they could relate to Scrooge or see any hope for him.. When asked to help the poor by charity workers, he answers "If they would rather die, they had better do it and decrease the surplus population." Scrooge is a dark character, so far it would seem from any hope of redemption that when it comes it's all the more joyful.Secondly, "Scrooged" is basically a farce and so by its very nature everything is exaggerated. That's how a farce works. If Bill Murray's character had been a mildly grumpy man it would have fallen flat. Everything is exaggerated to its maximum effect. Bill Murray's Frank Cross isn't bad, he's horrible. As the movie begins he does something awful, then he does something even worse, then he tops even that, totally plumbing the depths of being an unprincipled scoundrel. There's seemingly no limit to how awful Frank Cross can be. Murray's deadpan delivery and general air of condescension embody the character perfectly. He plays it beautifully, too: no winks at the camera, just totally straight as the boss from hell. It's his film, he had to carry it and he did.The film was directed by action movie director Richard Donner between "Lethal Weapon I and II. The production became well known for its general air of disagreement between Donner, Murray and screenwriters Mitch Glazer and Michael O'Donoghue. Each seemed to have their own idea of the film, with the writers saying Donner did not know how to shoot comedy and not liking Murray's improvisations, which included the major speech he gives at the end. Donner thought Murray was difficult but admired his professionalism. Murray had not made a picture since "Ghostbusters: four years earlier and felt stressed by the pressure to carry the film. He also suffered some physical reactions to the artificial snow, but this might have actually improved his portrayal of Cross..Somehow it all worked out. It's a bit long here and there and Fran;s change of heart seems a bit too sudden, but that's what the story is about.The film knocks you out of any preconceived expectations by opening with Donner satirizing himself with an armed invasion of Santa's Workshop at the North Pole ("The Day the Reindeer Died":). It features an actual action star, then goes off in several other unexpected directions until you don't know what will happen next and that's the general way the whole film is. It's also loaded with unexpected casting and surprise cameos which are all part of the fun. Some of this may have lost some effect as time has gone by and new viewers may not understand some of the references, but it's still a funny film even if you don't know who all the actors are. It also satirizes the notion that any publicity is good publicity, the industry obsession with awards and the quest for network ratings. The supporting cast is excellent, even Murray's own younger brother playing Frank Cross's younger brother James. The film was a hit in 1988, though not a huge hit. Over subsequent decades it has picked up many fans and is now a holiday classic.

Coolest thing about this film is how it spins the Christmas carol formula. With hundreds of different Christmas carol films always taking place in the same time period just with different actors or different characters. This movie brings life by making it very modern, at least for the late 80s. Bill Murray plays a film producer working on a Christmas carol film whose life mirrors Scrooge. The ghosts in this film are hilarious and have some of the best scenes, the new plot twists and threads are interesting although feel slightly unrealistic, although considering how slapstick this film is that shouldn't really be a problem. My biggest gripe with this film is I just didn't find it funny, it had all the perfect jokes to be funny but nothing overly made me laugh out loud, bill Murray also shouts a whole lot for some reason. With that being said this is still a very good Christmas classic and an awesome take on a Christmas carol.

This was the most bill murray of bill murray of bill murray movies ever. Plays the same smarmy character he always plays. What you think of this movie depends on how much over the top bill murray-ing you can take. He really is a gross jerk. I feel like maybe he was playing himself. Like his old girlfriend would be so into him and immediately swoon the minute he pays attention to her (right after making out with a solid gold dancer on live tv - haha hilareous right?). It is so ridiculous. In the end he doesn't seem redeemed he just seems insane. Like seriously a mental breakdown right before he commits suicide. His assistent holds the studio at gunpoint (which def isn't funny anymore) while he makes a truly deranged speech while crying. It's more disturbing than sweet. Maybe that was the point. I'm not entirely sure. I guess I don't get it. Now I can cross it off my list. It's like how wes anderson has just got too wes anderson. This is the same. Just too much free reign bill murray. I chuckled a few times but not enough to make this any kind of classic.

It's been on my watch list for a while now. Didn't like it much when I finally sat down to watch it. Bill Murray's character just screams all the time, that's it. I understand the Scrooge-character is supposed to be unlikable but Murray's character is unlikeable in an obnoxious sort of way that it makes it hard to believe he's redeemable. The movie as a whole is very over the top, but not in a good way. Half of the lines are unintelligible due to sound editing or the actors' delivery. It felt kind of like a fever dream. There were a couple good laughs but not good enough to make me watch it again.

4/4: Scrooged (1988)(8/10): Here's a true gem, A Christmas Carol with a twist!Scrooged is a more contemporary retelling of the classic Scrooge tale.It follows, Frank, a selfish and cynical television executive who is not a fan of Christmas.He sends cheap gifts to his family and employees, airs the least Christmasy Christmas shows and movies during the holidays, fires his workers for saying that they should do something different and more wholesome for the holidays and even uses others misfortune to further himself.He is then one night nearing the holidays by the ghost of his former boss who was a legend in the business warning him that he needs to change and he will be visited by three ghosts.He is then sent down a spiral of insanity as the ghosts show him the error of his ways in order to change him from being Scrooged to a Saint.Bill Murray stars in this more modern and slightly darker version of the story and he is also joined by Bobcat Goldthwait in a more under appreciated yet very quirky holiday film.We have Richard Donner directing who was also behind The Omen, The Goonies and the Lethal Weapon movies and he is accompanied by legendary composer Danny Elfman who has worked with Tim Burton on several occasions as well as the Spider-Man Trilogy, Hellboy II, and more films.The Portrayal of Frank by Murray is great as he really shows his selfishness followed by his denial to accept that what he's experiencing is in fact real and then his mental breakdown once he fully realizes it is happening followed by him getting more and more cracked up after each encounter.Might I add that the ghosts are all fantastically designed, with my favourite overall being the ghost of Christmas Past as he has stereotypical New Yorker attitude coupled with a dry sense of humour but overall design is Ghost of Christmas Future even though we see the least of him, his screen time isn't wasted.When he is first seen and he is just taking up the various tv screens to form his face and then we see that huge skeletal hand reach out behind Frank, man that effect is so cool.The score is not one of Elfman's most notable but it's a nice little piece nonetheless.Overall the film is just the right kind of movie for the holiday season, this one is a much recommended watch.

latest_10_reviews.review_title: Wonderful comedic adaptation of the classic
latest_10_reviews.review_text: Charming, magical, funny and sweet. Great cast, costumes, writing. I watch it every Christmas! Carol Kane.as the ghost of Christmas present, played as a tough as nails, take no prisoners fairie, the always silly and delightful Bill Murray- endearing even when being an awful human being, sweet Karen Allen as his girfriend, and even Robert Mitchum and Buddy Hacket, John Houseman, Lee Majors...C'Mon! I can't find it playing this year, (so far at least), and I'm truly upset/disappointed. Grab an eggnog or a hot toddy, put on your silly Christmas pajama, and settle in for a goofy, fantastical night of story telling and giggles!

latest_10_reviews.review_title: Watching for the second time, I remember...
latest_10_reviews.review_text: I enjoyed the movie, but watching for the second time I saw there was one glaring flaw, and I'm not sure if it's the responsibility of the new director for this second film, or the actor.Jennifer Lawrence's over-acting (limited to 2 or 3 significant moments) doesn't maim the movie, but it certainly momentarily breaks the spell. First, as Katniss ascends the tube to the arena, Once (more than once?) when she's in the arena, and once more in the last couple of minutes of the film.We had the same kind of crazed in the latter seasons of Handmaid's Tale; one presumes the directors didn't have a robust imagination for alternatives than "crazed expression #24".It's as if the characters, contrary to most reasonable people I think, actually hadn't reached the point of not being surprised by anything that might occur, in spite of all that has occurred to date.Otherwise, a very good film, well done all-around.

I think this movie offers it all. That may seem strange as I have only rated a 7 but in truth I'm not sure what I would've wanted, it might just be the fact that this movie is just another part of the story that it can't deliver everything. In my opinion it is much better than the first movie as my only real complaint from that one was that the hunger games action didn't really start until the last hour. Although this film had a similar set up, I found the build up to the return to the games was much more interesting and set up a brilliant and thrilling game. This film is clearly a major set up for a larger story but I am looking forward to watching more!

An enormous step up in storytelling & filmmaking. Frustratingly bleak & hopeless with great set design. Intense, mysterious, & emotional as the plot plays out. New cast is impossible not to love..
..
An enormous step up in storytelling & filmmaking. Frustratingly bleak & hopeless with great set design. Intense, mysterious, & emotional as the plot plays out. New cast is impossible not to love..
..
An enormous step up in storytelling & filmmaking. Frustratingly bleak & hopeless with great set design. Intense, mysterious, & emotional as the plot plays out. New cast is impossible not to love.

latest_10_reviews.review_title: Much Faster, More Visceral, and More Intriguing
latest_10_reviews.review_text:
The First Hunger Games film did something special. It told a compelling Dystopian type story. This film took the best elements from the first film and REALLY expanded upon them.The first film introduced the idea of the games to us, but this film gave us the argument and philosophy of why the games existed in the first place. This film also did a great job with expanding the world of Panem and it's character storytelling.As far as character moments go, there were alot of great moments from both Jennifer Lawrence and Josh Hutcherson. Both of them struggling with life after the Games, and how they deal with the
savagery they've witnessed while going through another round of even more savagery in this film. Both are at there peak in this film and continue to shine and grow.Shoutout to Donald Sutherland though. We definitly get to spend more time with him in this film and we really get to see more of what drives him to do what he does, and we get to see some really awesome moments between his character President Snow, and Katniss Everdeen.The imagery and cinematography I believe have really stepped up since the last movie. There were some really beautiful shots. And the music is even more of a standout in this one.Other than that, like I said before, the action is a lot more savage than previous, and definitely more faster paced in my opinion. The Choreography and the action scenes were done really well.I know people say that this film may be the best film in The Hunger Games franchise, but in my opinion, both the 1st and 2nd could be potentially tied for first in my mind. You can't g owrong with either.

My biggest problem with the first film was its low production value look.Holy Blazes! Does this film absolutely crush it in terms of production value. Amazing effects. Fantastic sets. Great color and camera work. Did you know they used handheld imax cameras for this film? Absolutely fantastic! This movie is a visual feast. The hunger games team was obviouslyt alloted a fat ton of money! I mean come on! They won over Philip Seymour Hoffman, the absolute legend, what a great actor. He kills it in this film, and casts a great menacing shadow on this film.This film carries the same (if not more powerful) emotional levity that the first film has.Great story.Great characters.AMAZING SCORE. By gosh, James Newton Howard absolutely crushed this series film score. Some of his best work.A part of me wants to give this film a 9, its just so well done.These films continue to depict the struggle of Tyranny Order, Chaos, Revolution and Anarchy in a profound real way.I better walk away before i give this film a 9...

The first Hunger Games had some good ideas going for, and some things that made it stand out from typical young adult fantasy adventures, and it was an overall decent feature.This sequel, however, is vastly superior, and could be likened to The Empire Strikes Back to the original Star Wars. Not in quality, perhaps - but it does follow up on the original formula and turns it on its head, developing its characters in a more complex light, and is all around darker and higher on the stakes.The actors have really grown into their roles more, and Jennifer Lawrence in particular is stellar as a strong heroine. The effects and action set pices are also far superior in this compared to the original film.Overall, great sequel that elevates and already interestin formula in spectacular ways!

latest_10_reviews.review_title: This one stands above the others.
latest_10_reviews.review_text: Fearing an uprising over Katniss and Peeta's success at The Hunger Games, he changed the rules for the upcoming 75th games, the pair are right back inside the deadly games, only this time, the competition is much tougher.With the release of the new film just around the corner, I wanted to revisit them all, my feelings haven't changed, I still think that this is the best of the lot so far, I think it's better than the original film.I think it's a little slow to start, the impression you get early on is that it's an in depth look at life for Katniss and Peeta after the games, but when the twist comes, the film really does open up.It's not overlong, I'm glad they didn't push it out any further.There are some exciting sequences, these games really do provide a few thrills.Jennifer Lawrence is excellent as Katniss, her performance for me is superior to her previous one, she's excellent, as are Philip Seymour Hoffman and Donald Sutherland. Toby Jones, still doesn't work for me here.Best of the lot for me.8/10.

latest_10_reviews.review_title: Amazing film best hunger games movie
latest_10_reviews.review_text: This movie was amazing and made the series more entertaining. The first movie of course it was good but it was a little boring compared to this one. This movie introduces many new characters enhancing the plot. The main characters have to get tangled up with characters such as Finnick and Johanna. They make the plot way more intresting, especially with Finnicks personality and how he interacts with Katniss and Peeta.This movie also builds up extremely well to the point of the next movie, mockingjay part 1. At first it just makes it seem like they're playing the games like normal and, yes it does start of with that for most of the movie. Then at the end you can see that it was all building up to throwing over the capital when Katniss is picked up semi unconscious by the crane. Amazing film definitely the best out of the movies.

Hunger Games: Catching Fire is the second installment in The Hunger Games franchise, and so far, I'm not so excited. The only reason I watch these movies is to get ready for the upcoming one now in November. But about this one. Well, it was just ok. The plot is taking place just after part one, and things are starting to get out of control when Katniss Everdeen is changing the Hunger Games, and starts to make people mad. After that it goes a while and a new Hunger Games is out once again, with the same characters from part one. So honestly, nothing new was changed, just a new game. You know they are going to survive, because it's too predictable. Some new challenges but didn't impress too much. But I have to admit that part two was better made than the original one. The stunts were creative and well done. Great camera-work and epic angles, what gave this an extra cinematic experience. Entertaining for most time, so I give most points for that. They showed a bigger connection between the friend group in the games, but I wished some more character development form the main characters. I also wished they could show more of the world outside, because they haven't showed it so much yet. And the music. Well, The Hunger Games theme is fun to listen, but not for the thousand time. They could put more variety in the music score. The nostalgic and heroic theme was getting my out of control sometimes. But overall, this wasn't such a bad movie. It got some technical and historical problems that I would change, but at the same time it was very entertaining and good action included, with a pretty cool cliffhanger at the end! So if you liked the first one, then you should watch this one, too, but don't have high expectations.

latest_10_reviews.review_title: The Hunger Games: Catching Fire (2013) Changes that improved the franchise
latest_10_reviews.review_text: I consider the first film in The Hunger Games franchise to be very mediocre. The steering is one of the points that bothers me the most in the previous one. However, in this second film the screenwriters and director are different. This detail completely changed the quality of the sequel, making it far superior to its predecessor. Even though it's better, it's still nothing incredible and revolutionary. It's a generic film with interesting scenes, but in the end it doesn't become anything memorable. The first act is the most interesting moment and best explores this problematic system in the universe of The Hunger Games. After the first act, we enter again into a dull story that serves as an excuse to become yet another generic action film. There's nothing special about the film, but it manages to be fun at different times.

movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Mayhem

latest_10_reviews.review_title: "They look like little Shreks to me."
latest_10_reviews.review_text: FILM: 8/10.As a 43-year-old original fan of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles comics, cartoons, and the live-action films from the 90s, my expectations were as low as a pizza in the sewer. Many attempts to recapture the turtle magic had fallen flatter than a deflated pizza crust. However, Seth Rogen, Evan Goldberg, and the writers behind Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Mayhem pleasantly surprised me, delivering the best TMNT content in decades.Featuring actual teenagers as the voice cast adds a pepperoni twist to the turtles, infusing their characters with the energy and idiocy of adolescence. The tangents and teenage spirals perfectly capture that age, earning a ninja nod of approval. The rest of the cast, a deep roster of talent, brings the characters to life with flair.Ditching the usual focus on the Shredder and the Foot Clan, the film takes a refreshing turn with Ice Cube's Superfly and a rogues' gallery of secondary villains. It's a topping of variety that's been missing in previous TMNT projects.The animation is as unique as a turtle shell, and Mutant Mayhem does for TMNT what Into the Spider-Verse did for Spider-Man, giving it a fresh and visually captivating spin.Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross's score, like the perfect blend of cheese and tomato sauce, hits all the right notes. Their fusion of acoustic and electronic elements creates a varied soundtrack that complements each scene like the perfect pizza pairing.After enduring some disappointing Michael Bay-produced films, this reboot was like a pizza delivery in a half shell, exactly what the TMNT franchise needed. Bring on the sequel, and let the turtles keep kicking shell with their newfound freshness! A turtle power revival that's as satisfying as a slice with all your favorite toppings.FORMAT: 4K Ultra HD Blu-rayVIDEO: 10/10.Upscaled 4K presentation, Detail level: Excellent, Colour reproduction: Excellent, Level accuracy: Excellent, Encode: Excellent, Master condition: ExcellentAUDIO: 10/10.Dolby Atmos audio, Dialogue reproduction: Excellent, Soundtrack & effects clarity: Excellent, Dynamics: Excellent, Surround sound presentation: Excellent, LFE content: ExcellentMOOFIEMETER: 8/10.

latest_10_reviews.review_title: Fun flick, but I hope the sequel is better.
latest_10_reviews.review_text: The problem with origin super hero movies is they're all the same on the surface, that's why Spider-Man Homecoming skipped Peter Parker's whole origin story because we've heard it a thousand times, but TMNT isn't quite as popular so they had to go over the basics. As a result, the characters and animation are fun, but the story could have been written by an AI. A sequel should take care of that though. In the next movie, we'll have these fun charters already established and the story can go wherever they want to take it, which is exciting!Speaking of the characters, they're super fun and acted by actual teenagers! They're pretty annoying but in a "teenaged boys having harmless fun" kinda way which I really vibed with.I appreciate the animation isn't the simple 3D Pixar animation we've been seeing for the past 2 decades, but I'd be remiss if I didn't say I thought this was the same studio that made the Spider-Verse movies, turns out they're entirely different and unrelated. I enjoy unique art styles, and they try to separate themselves from the Spider-verse films, but it's obvious that some studio exec said "I want a movie like the Spider-Verse movies" and thus we got TMNT Mutant Mayhem. That's not to say the animation is bad or anything, but to me it felt like the movie didn't have an identity. It didn't help having all the pop music needle drops either.This movie will be incredibly dated in just 10 years with all its modern references, but hey it's fun now and that's all that really matters.Overall, I'd definitely recommend the movie, but don't hold your breath for anything crazy like the Spider-Verse movies this film was so clearly trying to copy.

latest_10_reviews.review_title: A total disaster, polluting the Turtles for this generation
latest_10_reviews.review_text: STAR RATING: ***** Brilliant **** Very Good *** Okay ** Poor * AwfulDespite protecting the city from crime, the Turtles, and their master Splinter (Jackie Chan) must live beneath it in the sewers, as the public spurn them because they don't look like them. In the middle of this, the city is under attack from the criminal mastermind, Superfly (Ice Cube), a giant, sludgy bug who's got the local crime monopoly under his control. Cue a run in with cool, streetwise aspiring reporter April O' Neill (Ayo Edibiri), with whom they strike a deal: they'll let her into their world, in return for positive exposure in the social media world April is fluent with.I tend to be fairly loyal, with any franchise with a long established fan base, as it goes through the years, meaning different things to new generations in new incarnations. One that maybe drifted away was the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, which remained fundamentally aimed at kids, without the dark potential to explore, like with the Batman films. And so Mutant Mayhem, the latest version of the original cartoon, passed me by, especially with 'permanent teenager' Seth Rogan, who I'm no great fan of, being one of the writers and producers. But, I've finally given it a go on streaming...and it's even worse than I thought, for reasons I'd never have thought.Directors Geoff Rowe and Kyle Spears are going with an experimental style with the animation, which may appeal to some, but comes off as crude and garish to those of a certain taste. But what's even worse is how they've mangled the characters and their backstories. Jackie Chan's Splinter has morphed from his original calm, restrained manner, into some funky hipster, who plays them old school hip hop tunes that came out before most of the target demographic were born, and won't remember. To be fair, the Turtles retain their original distinctive characteristics, but what is up with Donatello's voice, sounding like some infant who's just learned to talk?!? No wonder it seems voiceover artist Micah Abbey is the only one too embarrassed to have a publicity headshot.Crucially, though, the plot is threadbare, the humour has far more misses than hits, and the whole thing feels like a hideous mangling of the original version, that hints it may be time for the Turtles to put their weapons back in their holsters. *

To start off it was an easy watch for me due to the music as it was clearly compiled by someone who grew up around the same era as me.The art style was really quite nice but for a poster, not for the film. It didn't work and a different style would have been much better.It's not really an all ages thing. It just wasn't suitable for adults. The dialogue was really annoying for anyone age 10+. The script was the same, very immature.I felt like there were lots of nods to different popular things to try and score brownie points with everyone, such as BTS and Attack in Titan.The whole thing was just boring and fell flat. It was quite simply a bit of boring feature length cartoon.Just nothing to like with a kids story that did nothing, kids dialogue that was annoying and a soundtrack and art style that didn't really work.Yet another disappointment.I'm actually getting so disappointed with Hollywood films that are complete rubbish, getting decent reviews that I am probably going to return to not watching films out of the US anymore. They just have no substance and keep getting worse.

I wasn't quite sure what to expect watching this movie. First of all I am not a huge fan of the style of animation. So, for me it was a bit of a big strike against. But the biggest strike against it is changing the characters and the backstory. Villains weren't really villains and weren't allowed to shine.It's campy, full of cliches and quite silly. That's the part that works. Voice acting is quite good. There really isn't much for character development. The storyline is overly simplistic. Being, primarily a kids movie, that was expected.Despite all the flaws it is entertaining but it starts from what is the TMNT's.

latest_10_reviews.review_title: whoever wrote this needs to quit
latest_10_reviews.review_text: I grew up with the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles show from the 87, saw all the movies up until this one. I was not impressed with the last 2 remakes but as average as they were at least they didn't make me upset. I don't even know where to start. They changed the origin story which might which could have been okay if it was well-written, but that was not the case. Everything seemed so bland and unbelievable. I almost lost it when there was a scene where Splinter was sitting in a couch scrolling through his cell phone like an old man having nothing else to do. The writers tried so hard to be smart and funny but to me failed at all levels. Most of the jokes didn't land and I couldn't care less or sympathize with most of the characters. This seems like one of those "modern" remakes that are so popular these days. I could almost feel Seth Rogen's touch all over the material. I still liked the animation and the voice acting was decent. Other than that it's an empty shell. Even at 100 minutes it felt so long.

latest_10_reviews.review_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Mayhem is regurgitation served as child's play. I actually feel sick after watching it. No joke.
latest_10_reviews.review_text: Nerd Turtles (2023) is a batch of sensory overload and gross animation. Junk food for the mind. It actually made me feel sick after watching, and I don't know if that's done intentionally.I would have nice things to say about TMNT: Mutant Mayhem, but for whatever reason, it just makes me feel awful discussing the fact that I watched it, so without wasting time, here's a hot take on the movie instead:I'd probably enjoy this movie a lot more if I were a kid, but being honest, I think even the most die-hard Ninja Turtle fans know this movie didn't live up to their expectations. For one, the style is fitting, but it lacks in delivery for a number of reasons. Some of the character designs are freakishly off-putting for some reason. Not the main turtle designs, but a lot of the others. April O'Neil, at many points, had eye problems. (I'm not sure if I'm the only one who noticed that.)Another problem with making a movie in the same vein as Spider-Verse is that, while TMNT: Mutant Mayhem doesn't directly copy the style verbatim, it does strike me as being a little bit low quality for trying to replicate the personality without understanding why the personality of Spider-Verse worked in the first place. Spider-Verse 1 and 2 may have set a high bar for what could be accomplished with visual aesthetics, but they never sacrificed simplicity. On the other hand, TMNT: Mutant Mayhem tries to do it's own thing, but at the expense of battering the Ninja Turtle source material in order to fit in. There were other problems with the animation outside of this, but I'll give the movie a pass in this area.The writing is so generic, it actually makes me want to cry. There could be so much more done with this franchise, and if they do make a sequel, I'm hoping they learn from what stunk about Mutant Mayhem, because a lot of the writing had its high points and a lot more low points. There's nothing necessarily wrong with the premise, and the ideas stick to the wall, but without spoiling anything, it's clear this movie is made to hype up the next movie and not as its own stand-alone film. This is the "how do you do, fellow kids" to the Ninja Turtles franchise.I am able to tolerate this movie, I just don't want to think about it anymore. I'll give credit where credit is due and say that it didn't eat me inside, but it just makes me not want to look at another pop culture reference ever again. This movie had too many of those, to which I will add, "Am I not turtley enough for the turtle club?" If what I said was hard for you to endure, that's how I felt about this movie. *sigh*

latest_10_reviews.review_title: Pretty Good, Made For Kids (As It Should Be)
latest_10_reviews.review_text: While I did think this was a pretty good effort on the Turtles, probably the best since the old movies I grew up on. The art style was excellent, very unique. There were parts where it looked almost like claymation mixed with illustration or something.This is the first time I've seen the Turtles treated like actual TEENAGERS. I said so to a couple of people who said "Didn't they always act like Teenagers?" to which I say NO. They acted like Surfers. They also made an effort to incorporate some more of the comic/cartoon characters that people are less familiar with, which I thought was nice.The movie was not without flaws. First off, there's no Shredder. I get that he's not the only villain, but I was hoping for some Shredder. The soundtrack was mostly fine, but they repeatedly used the song "Ante Up" like it was the theme of the movie and that song very flatly glorifies armed robbery. If you're going to gear your movie towards kids, maybe be a little more conscious of the messages you're sending. Also I don't mind the basic changes to April, but why did they shape her like a potato?Overall it was an enjoyable enough kids movie for an adult to get through, it had some genuine humor and writing to it which I did not expect.

This film did it right. TMNT has survived for nearly forty years, and took them getting back to their roots to make them popular once more. This movie is suitable for kids and adults. Those adults who have kids now, and watched these characters their entire life. The animation is a next level, making it look like art rather than animation. And, for once, the voice actually sound like teenagers. It took them too long to figure that out. There's also an array of actors who voice many characters, it's worth taking a google search. I will probably end up watching this film again. They also don't go for the standard villain. Saving him for next time.

It's cringe. I didn't expect this. This movie is just a movie for 5 years old kids, really. They will laugh, especially on that type of silly jokes about family, outdated dad and etc. I am 28 and this is a very sad thing to realize that TMNT universe is getting worser every time. All-time's best is 2003 TMNT animated series Seasons 1-5. Just try to compare it, 80's turtles, Seasons 6-7 of 2003 TMNT, Michael Bay's movie and its sequel, Nickelodeon era, and this one are on the same shame boat, it's all as bad as it can be, very silly created content. Sell the rights to Marvel, please. It may be an option to make TMNT great again.

latest_10_reviews.review_title: A comedy that wants to be political
latest_10_reviews.review_text: But fails. Honestly if you just watch the first 2/3 and then turn it off, you'd be doing yourself a favor.Long dead are the days of entertainment for the sake of entertainment, I'm mostly desensitized to the contrived narratives by this point. The movie was for the most part enjoyable before they stopped trying to be funny all together, which was a shame. Obviously I didn't have my hopes up after the lizzo song was playing, and it just sounding like a bunch of forced mainstream narratives. But this did get worse over time.The amazing aesthetic choices, colorful set pieces and comedic decisions made my experience overall positive, although I'm the last person to be excited for more corporate, regurgitated identity politics in what should be a harmless show.

latest_10_reviews.review_title: Biggest Movie but not the best of 2023
latest_10_reviews.review_text: Barbie was definitely the biggest movie to come out in 2023, with the hype train in full flow before the release. The cast was perfect and the soundtrack across multiple artists all running to get a bite of the cherry was also quite good, most hit the charts upon release.The story of the film hits home the meaning of Barbie, on how she can be anything or do any career she wants to do in a time when Barbie was released as a toy, women were still trying to get a foot on the world and this really hits home in the film.Very good ending and our stereotypical Barbie is actually the least stereotypical as she gains a form of conscience after embarking out into the real world and begins to question her existence.Definitely the biggest release of 2023, a very funny and quirky adaption of our well known Toy Barbie.

latest_10_reviews.review_title: This is not a Barbie film - watch Life Size instead
latest_10_reviews.review_text: This movie is all about Ken. And this was a very big issue for me as it was so hyped up to be a 'feminist' film. Was there a big Barbie production number with Margot Robbie singing? Ken has - at least two big song and dance numbers. Sure it started with Barbie asking who she really is, but in the end it was Ken who asked the big questions and got some answers too - if you could even find your way into this mess of a fluff. At least this film have taught me that if a movie is too heavily promoted which even included a Barbie burger meal set or Barbie milk tea, it must be that desperate to sell because it must be that bad.

latest_10_reviews.review_title: Way too much in this movie to be described in 600 words.
latest_10_reviews.review_text:
As in 2001, the first 5 minutes sums up the entire movie. And like 2001, you will be asked to think, and think in unconventional ways outside your usual comfort zone(s). It doesn't matter what particular side of the Great Debate you are on, or think you are on, this movie will ask you questions honestly and difficult. And will ask you to be honest in answering them for yourself. All the while, the humour is both gentle and subtle, a very British reading of the Barbie story.Reading some of the commens on this board, it is clear that Barbie does not fall into trap of fulfilling expectations. We can leave that to movies like Saving Private Ryan. Barbie a courage all of its challenge in different ways. It is unfortunate but not unexpected that in 2023 there are so many who prefer the comfort of their own dollhouses.The following may be spoilers:
Kudos to Mattel for having the honesty and courage to laugh at its corporate self.Was Gosling channeling his inner. Michael Flately for one scene and. Zefran Cochrane for another.?And yes, it's part documentary.

latest_10_reviews.review_title: Still don't really know what to think of this movie
latest_10_reviews.review_text: I watched this movie a couple of days ago. I didn't really know what to think of it and even after a few days of gentle reflection I haven't been able to draw a definite conclusion.It is quite silly, over the top, laughable, ridiculous, cute and charming on the one hand. On the other hand it does have a deeper message and a good one as well.Because it the story is so over the top and quite hysterical, it really shows you well how conservative en patriarchic standards are still dictating our society. Maybe it needs to be portrayed in such a maner to wake us up. The mirror is funny, but harsh at the same time.Some friends are a huge fan ans some are definitely not. I am somewhat in the middle, but am still ruminating.

I might be one of the last people on the planet to see this movie, I deliberately held off because of the hype. I ended up caving and I'm glad I did and let the period of high expectations pass. This meant I could enjoy it for what it is which is lots of fun. The political messages were present but not too in your face, more a sort of background thought as you leave the cinema. As a 49 year old woman I can't say it spoke to me deeply or shocked nd surprised me any way but I did get some laughs. Margot and Ryan are brilliant and I'm sure will soon be reunited in a prequel or sequel. Calling it now.

latest_10_reviews.review_title: I'm so glad I waited until it was released on HBO Max and I can't believe everyone claims it's for adults
latest_10_reviews.review_text: With all the hype about this movie I was really tempted to see it on the big screen. Not for kids, deep and funny? Count me in! I just didn't get around to seeing it and I'm so glad. It would obviously bore young children, but how did it not bore every other adult as well? What a lame comedy-only one scene made me chuckle, the rest of the "funny" parts made me roll my eyes. I'd say it's more of a tween movie, or even teen if you keep them under a rock. But I don't know what the excuse is for adults thinking it's an amazing, brilliant comedy. And the whole deep part was pretty lame as soon as we saw that Barbie realized that the real world isn't how it is in hers.

This is by far not the perfect movie, but I enjoyed it more than Oppenheimer, which I was not able to finish.This movie is definitely head above a lot of other media in terms of attention to little details and the costumes. Loved this side of it, and I remember seeing lots of YouTube videos that went over all the details and how they are connected to real life or to other media. It also has a really good pacing, and overall feels more like an adult fairytale. Which may not be something for everyone, obviously.I remember when it just came out a lot of people were praising the show for how females are portrayed, and bashed it for how males are portrayed. And there were some who did the reverse. I would say that both sides are correct. Not to go too much into details, patriarchy is depicted as the evil of the world, and matriarchy is the only way to save it. This is not only not true, but it is also shallow, and ignoring real examples of matriarchic rule.At the same time, the movie does touch upon real issues that men face in real life, like the need to fight for even a slither of attention. This is good, but it gets kind of brushed off at the end, almost as if it did not matter, that that's what brought about Kendome. "Kenough" shirt is a good message, but it gets overpowered by the main message, that it is enough for women to just be ordinary. Which is also a good message, but...
The movie just forgot that in reality you need equality. You need both sides to be present and finding common ground. It is ok to be ordinary for both sides, and both sides can do amazing things. To be honest, for more than first half of the movie, I thought that would be the final message, but in the end it was muddied by "women are better", which felt disingenuous and worsened overall experience. The final scene, though did even more damage, but maybe I just did not get it, since I am a guy.Either way, it was more or less an enjoyable experience. Overhyped? Probably yes. Worth a watch? Also, probably yes, if you temper your expectations.

The best way to describe Barbie is as a 1960s psychedelic musical with a incoherent plot. How did Barbie make so much money? The movie started off strong and then took a wrong turn into Wonkaland.Barbie should be fun. I found this very depressing. Why is Barbie crying all the time? Why is death talked about so much? Why is not any joy found in being yourself? This is a kid's toy. The film is aimed at teens and adults which don't care for Barbies anyway.The plot was all over the place - The empowerment of women, Barbie becomes real, a rom-com, an action movie, etc. And what was with the random dance numbers and singing? Part musical, part comedy,part parody, part drama equals a hot mess.I loved Margot in I,Tonya but this was a disaster.

So much has been said about this film. It made huge amounts of money and had an incredible start at the box office. I wanted to see it, but the stars didn't align. Since I had read no reviews and had not talked to anyone who had seen it, I went in quite objectively. Our kids had a Barbie or two around the house, but they didn't rule their world. That said, I think I'm a pretty open minded movie viewer. This film is far from the phenomenon the press made it out to be. I enjoyed the incredible sets and recreations of the pink world. Also, the introduction to that world and all the Barbies and Kens was quite amazing. As others have said, however, is that it becomes wordy and preachy in the final third. I started looking at the clock which is not a good sign. The cast is good, although Ryan Gosling isn't dull enough to be Ken. He is never boring, even at the beginning. I'm glad I saw this because it is a cultural phenomenon (even though it doesn't deserve it). The message is a good one and spot on. It's just delivered in a less than stellar way.

This movie, about a Victorian-era miser taken on a journey of self-redemption, is a great fantasy movie!It's an adventurous cinematic experience filled with elements consisting of everything from horror to joy to tragedy. The animation is slightly outdated where it now looks like cut-scenes from the game Read Dead Redemption 2 (2018), but if you set your mind like it's 2009, it's actually visually stunning. The movie has a great attention to details, and there's a lot to discover during the protagonist Scrooge's journey. I personally find it less enjoyable from when Scrooge gets hunted by the coachman until he sees his own tombstone because the action feels more coincidental than purposeful, but that's only for that part. The rest is very captivating and touching. Anyway, it's noticeable that the actors do their best because their performances perfectly complete the characters, and the cinematography and the fantastic sound design make the movie a great example of an experience fitting for the big screen. The score also helps to create a diverse atmosphere that introduces vibes like Christmas in general, but also suspense and excitement. Overall, the movie contains a beautiful story with a unique experience for the Christmas holiday.This is a visually stunning and emotionally resonant movie that offers a unique cinematic experience. The animation may be slightly outdated, but the performances, cinematography, and sound design are all top-notch. A must-see for anyone seeking a captivating Christmas story.

After Tom Hanks performed multiple roles in "The Polar Express," the egomaniacal Jim Carey no doubt couldn't rest until he surpassed Hanks, at least in the number of roles played in a single movie. But as always he utterly overacted each role, putting the many fine nuances of Dickens's extraordinary classic into the background. Fortunately, he was unable to make this inconsistent travesty of the original story any worse: it was so bad, so full of preposterous variations on the original, that it would have been impossible to bring it lower. As the movie progresses, scenes increasingly diverge from the original until the beautiful messages Dickens embedded in the story are overwhelmed by pretentious and unnecessary histrionics. As I say, the worst if the 30 something versions I've seen.

Now before we get to the negatives let us just say that the animation and execution was fantastic. The style and how each visit was different from one to another was breathtaking at times. But why only 7 stars.In the book there was a very important bit of writing that goes as such. 'They are Man's,' said the Spirit, looking down upon them. 'And they cling to me, appealing from their fathers. This boy is Ignorance. This girl is Want. Beware them both, and all of their degree, but most of all beware this boy, for on his brow I see that written which is Doom, unless the writing be erased. Deny it.' cried the Spirit, stretching out its hand towards the city. 'Slander those who tell it ye. Admit it for your factious purposes, and make it worse. And abide the end.' It might just be one of the most important lessons in the book. Eb was appealed by his father which made him the person he was and by those words of the spirit he understood the "why" behind being generous, charitable and furthering mankind. It is a great lesson for this era.

Some reviewers have called this a "new" twist. Uh, no. It is, almost word for word, scene for scene, a faithful adaptation of the original book by Dickens.The good? Gorgeous scenery, intriguing camera angles and Scrooge's familiar character arc from curmudgeon to repentant soul trying to get things right.The not so good? The first two ghosts (also played by Carrey) are obnoxiously weird. Christmas Past looks like Jim Carey's smirking head floating incongruously above a wispy phantom torso. And Christmas Present is a jarring, cackling boor, with forced belly laughing at the most bizarre times.This is not a movie for young viewers. From the beginning funeral for Marley, complete with coins on the dead man's eyes, it is (as originally written) a macabre tale filled with terrifying images. The ghost of Marley is horrific.Most of the motion capture is mesmerizing, with only a few supporting characters looking flat and poorly animated.The film also cries out for a more inspiring musical score, instead relying on the crazy antics of multiple characters performed by Carrey to move the story along.Despite all this, I recommend it as a true book to movie transition, with some beautiful visuals.

latest_10_reviews.review_title: Interesting Interpretation but animation style gets creepy.
latest_10_reviews.review_text: Not a bad interpretation of A Christmas Carol and parts of the animation were great but then parts were rather creepy in a bad way and I don't mean the Ghosts/Spirits. Especially the children. You have great realism in parts and then AI type demon children. Strange way to make a movie. As for the dialog, kinda boring and parts of the spirits were either to vague to hear or just annoying.Jim Carrey performed okay but it's rather monotone overall. Same goes with the spirits. The movie was visually appealing but the tone was rather plain and could of been better. It's like you have one emotion and one emotion only throughout the movie. I think they were trying to go with a literal interpretation of A Christmas Carol but could of been better if not for the weird animation style and lack of overall emotion throughout the movie. Even the transformation comes across as unnatural and forced.Not a bad movie but could of been better.

British Reviewer.Although a score of 7.8/10 is quite high for an overly long, ridiculously Hollywood-ified version of Charles Dickens' novella A Christmas Carol. The sheer will and effort of Jim Carrey smashes this one out of the park and makes it a Christmas classic.Zemeckis really dragged out some shots, like the scene with the sign above the shop. The car-chase with a miniature Scrooge went on for AGES, I mean, Ebenezer is clearly terrified already by the prospect of his imminent demise. Does he really need pursuing by a carriage pulled by hell-beasts?Lastly, the grotesqueness of the characters is likely the most accurate portrayal of Victorian poor people but hilariously this is almost certainly a shortcoming of the animation style they chose to use.

The movie is about a grumpy old guy named scrooge who is not a fan of Christmas a bit. One night three ghost come and visit him. First the ghost shows him his own childhood and how it was. Then a different ghost shows the grandpa how others celebrate Christmas. Then the final ghost shows him into the future how he will be alone and spend his life alone. Then a plot twist happens and come Christmas morning the old grandpa is not grumpy anymore and now he is actually in the Christmas mood and goes around cheering and yelling to everyone saying merry Christmas and is acting like a child to everyone.

My husband finally got me to watch this with him tonight after him owning it for several years. This was the utmost boring thing ever. For the first 55 minutes, there were several 5 minute scenes that could have been only 30 seconds each. Also, I could not understand ninety percent of what anyone was saying, and could not figure out who some people were in relation to others due to that. The only good thing about this is that it finally ended. There's really nothing else to say about this but I'm required to type in a certain amount of characters. I can not see myself ever watching this again unless by force.

latest_10_reviews.review_title: Old man is terrorized by ghosts
latest_10_reviews.review_text: The tale of a greedy old man named Scrooge being taught a lesson on how Christmas is important is a tale almost as old as time. This rendition of the movie is probably my favorite take on this old tale. I love and hate the animation style (it gives me the heeby jeebies) but I am also a huge fan of anything that has to do with Jim Carrey so it may just be a personal bias. I also appreciate that no matter how many times this story is told they always seem to deliver the message on across, on how important Cherishing the ones around us are and how Christmas isn't all just presents and money. Instead it's showing love to our family by not only presents but just being grateful we have them.

This movie was an amazing movie to watch throughout its entire runtime. The animation throughout the movie was spectacular while also giving off very disturbing vibes throughout certain scenes. One particular scene that stood out to me and showed just how well the movie's animation and writing could be both disturbing while also entertaining would be when Scrooge was talking with the ghost of a Christmas present. Throughout the entire interaction I was both enthralled by the movements the camera used to convey motion throughout the town and at the same time horrified by the way the ghost of Christmas past interacted with scrooge during his death. The casting I thought was amazing and it's always good to see Jim Carrey not just play a comedy role but instead play a more serious, down to earth character. The only criticism I think I have to point out is that the movie's story is just like other movies out there. Someone who hates Christmas but later learns his lesson and becomes a joyful man has been used so much and probably done better by other movies that I have to deduct a single point. Other than that this movie is one that I feel like can be enjoyed by everyone in the family and I would totally recommend it for the holiday season.
